head.title: Please Go to the Principal's Office

hedline.hl1: Please Go to the Principal's Office

abstract.p: Bob Carr letter attributes shortage of school principals (Sept 3 article) to salaries that are not commensurate with the responsibilities that have been put on principals over the last three decades; cartoon

block.p: Re ''Nation's Schools Struggling to Find Enough Principals'' (front page, Sept. 3):
Re ''Nation's Schools Struggling to Find Enough Principals'' (front page, Sept. 3):

When I was first a principal in 1967, three students stayed at lunch and the rest went home. By the time I retired 10 years ago, all the students stayed, most for a hot lunch. This illustrates the changes in responsibility placed on principals.

These new tasks, which also include after-school programs, administering medication and social work, come on top of the traditional expectations that principals provide a safe climate for learning, maintain the building, supervise professionals and answer the questions and concerns of parents, students and superiors.

We have always tried to have public schools on the cheap by paying minimal salaries, so it is no surprise that we now see a shortage of principals. But giving veteran administrators pay that is equal to, or less than, that of first-year graduates of business schools will no longer work. A national commitment is needed so that our schools can have stable and effective leadership.
BOB CARR Ann Arbor, Mich., Sept. 3, 2000
